Instances.Description: At a city intersection, a camera with onboard computer vision monitors pedestrian crossing. This technology detects when people are waiting to cross the street, and automatically changes the traffic light. It ensures that people have enough time to cross. This benefits pedestrians with shorter wait times and safer crossings. No raw images of faces are sent to the cloud. Only information about location and traffic type (i.e., pedestrian, car or cyclist) are sent for further processing.
Instances.Name: Crosswalk Camera
Instances.Headline: De-identified computer vision helps pedestrians cross safely

Instances.Description: In a commercial district, decibel meters measure noise levels. This informs building codes, and helps to enable more dynamic use cases for buildings. Historic data can be collected, which alerts planners to how often noise levels exceed limits. Real time data can be used to alert bylaw infractions, minimising nuisance volume levels for residents. Voices are not recorded. Only information about volume, location and time are collected. Because this data is linked to specific locations, this data would not be publicly shared.
Instances.Name: Noise Monitoring
Instances.Headline: Sound Level Meter for managing nuisance and environmental noise

Instances.Description: In a post-secondary educational setting, cameras monitors physical distancing and supports contact tracing for management of Covid-19. This helps maintain a safe learning environment, and data is retained only for 30 days to support public health efforts. Only public health authorities can access personally identifying information.
Instances.Name: Covid-19 Distancing
Instances.Headline: Computer vision for physical distancing compliance

Instances.Description: A RFID reader uses radio waves to detect the proximity of an entry card near the lock, at which point the unique identifier of the card is transmitted to a security computer.
Instances.Name: Facility Access
Instances.Headline: A keyless entry system provides access to the building and spaces within.

Instances.Description:
Purpose: understand how the street is being used to inform future planning

Data Collected: de-identified images collected through Numina sensors are used to count pedestrians, bikes, and vehicles. Find out more by clicking the icons below.
Instances.Name: Numina (Tremont and Boylston)
Instances.Headline: Numina Sensor

Instances.Description:
Purpose: to understand how this loading zone is being used and its relationship to the adjacent sidewalk, storefronts, and bike lane.

Data Collected: de-identified images collected through Numina sensors are used to count pedestrians, bikes, and vehicles. Find out more by clicking the icons below.
Instances.Name: Numina (Seaport)
Instances.Headline: Numina Sensor

Instances.Description: Cameras record traffic footage, whose raw video data will be collected and saved on Secure Digital (SD) cards in the cameras, transferred via cloud server to a video analysis firm, and then deleted. The data will be used to study how changes to the street and/or within the Lyft app impact the experience of travelers with the intent of improving street safety.
Instances.Name: American Traffic Information Camera

Instances.Description: A Soofa sign acts like a digital bulletin board where people can post content in their neighborhood through a central, online platform. In order to measure the reach of its messaging, the sign's sensors count how many people come within an approximately 150-foot radius.
Instances.Name: Soofa Sign

Instances.Description: Verizon's Smart Communities IoT Solutions are a proof-of-concept for the City's Vision Zero Boston Program, an initiative for the City of Boston to prevent traffic crashes and resulting injuries and fatalities.
Instances.Name: Verizon Smart Streets Pilot

Instances.Description: At a city intersection, a camera with onboard computer vision monitors pedestrian crossing. This technology detects when people are waiting to cross the street, and automatically changes the traffic light. It ensures that people have enough time to cross. This benefits pedestrians with shorter wait times and safer crossings.
Instances.Name: DTPR Visual Ref
Instances.Headline: Computer vision sensor assesses mobility patterns

Instances.Description: At a city intersection, a camera with onboard computer vision monitors pedestrian crossing. This technology detects when people are waiting to cross the street, and automatically changes the traffic light. It ensures that people have enough time to cross. This benefits pedestrians with shorter wait times and safer crossings. No raw images of faces are sent to the cloud. Only information about location and traffic type (i.e., pedestrian, car or cyclist) are sent for further processing.
Instances.Name: _2020 GRIT Test: Computer Vision Camera
Instances.Headline: De-identified computer vision helps pedestrians cross safely

Instances.Description: In a busy train station, infrared occupancy sensors track the number of people who are in a given temperature control zone. When the room is very crowded/hot the sensors adjust the thermostat accordingly. When the room is empty/cold the sensors adjust the thermostat accordingly. This is meant to save energy by adjusting the thermostat. The data collected is non-identifiable, but does give information about building occupancy throughout the day.
Instances.Name: _2020 GRIT Test: Occupancy Sensor
Instances.Headline: Infrared for occupancy & temperature setting

Instances.Description: In a building with commercial and residential units, decibel meters measure noise levels. This informs building codes, and helps to enable more dynamic use cases for buildings. Historic data can be collected, which alerts planners to how often noise levels exceed limits. Real time data can be used to alert bylaw infractions, minimising nuisance volume levels for residents. Voices are not recorded. Only information about volume, location and time are collected. Because this data is linked to specific locations, this data would not be publicly shared.
Instances.Name: _2020 Grit Test: Sound Level Meter
Instances.Headline: Sound Level Meter for managing nuisance and environmental noise

Places.Name: KenmoreSq
Places.Headline: Kenmore Square along Commonwealth Avenue between Brookline Avenue and Kenmore Street
Places.Description: To study best practices for supporting safe, efficient, and multimodal streets, the City of Boston and Lyft will launch a joint-effort research pilot that measures the impact of combining digital in-app features alongside physical changes to street infrastructure in Kenmore Square. To analyze the before and after impacts of the Pilot Program, traffic cameras will be installed to collect traffic video footage at the intersection and street-level. The video footage will be analyzed for key performance indicators around congestion, safety, and curb access.

Accountability.Description: Lyft provides people with on-demand access to a variety of transportation options including shared car rides, bikeshare systems, electric scooters, and public transit partnerships.
Accountability.Name: Lyft
Accountability.Headline: Vendor

Accountability.Description: Soofa provides solar-powered, outdoor, 42-inch electronic displays for downtowns, neighborhoods, parks, and campuses.
Accountability.Name: Soofa
Accountability.Headline: Vendor

Accountability.Description: This data collection project was commissioned by the City of  Boston.
Accountability.Name: City of Boston

Accountability.Description: The Corporation of the City of Atlantic, or simply the City of Atlantis, is the public corporation that serves as the government of Oceao.
Accountability.Name: City of Atlantis

Accountability.Description: CanTrack is a regional railway operator that provides train services for business and pleasure
Accountability.Name: CanTrack

Accountability.Description: Shopping Commons has a historic place in our cities as one of the first outdoor shopping malls to be built in the boom of the 1950s.
Accountability.Name: Shopping Commons

Accountability.Description: Community College provides post-secondary vocational training and adult education.
Accountability.Name: Community College

Accountability.Description: Condo Management is responsible for the general operation, maintenance and administration of the building, on behalf of unit owners.
Accountability.Name: Condo Management

Purpose.Name: Accessibility
Purpose.Description: Ensures that everyone has equal access to a space or a service. Find out more about [accessibility] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accessibility) and [universal design] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_design)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Agency & Interaction
Purpose.Description: Enables you to control or interact with aspects of a space or a technology. Find out more about [interactive media] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_media) and [virtual reality] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Arts & Culture
Purpose.Description: Enables artistic and/or cultural expression. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_art)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Ecology
Purpose.Description: Supports the measurement or monitoring of the natural environment. Find out more about [the natural environment] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_environment), [ecology] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology) and [environmental science] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_science)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Energy Efficiency
Purpose.Description: Reduces energy use and/or helps conserve energy. Find out more about [energy efficiency] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficient_energy_use) and [energy conservation] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_conservation)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Enforcement
Purpose.Description: Used for enforcement of rules or regulations. Find out more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Entry
Purpose.Description: Supports authentication or validation in order to access a space or a service. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Access_control)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Fire & Emergency
Purpose.Description: Supports services that ensure public safety and health related to [emergencies] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency). Find out more about [emergency services] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_service).
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Health
Purpose.Description: Supports the measurement or monitoring of the aspects of the physical environment that impacts human health, such as [radiation] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radiation_protection) or [air quality] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution), or in specific contexts such as the workplace. Find out more about [environmental monitoring] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_monitoring) and [occupational health and safety] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupational_safety_and_health)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Inform
Purpose.Description: Supports the provision of information, for example about a location, a service, or to provide assistance
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Mobility
Purpose.Description: Supports how people and materials move around. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Planning & Decision-making
Purpose.Description: Supports the development of future plans; or to enable or measure the impact of a decision. Examples include [urban planning] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_planning)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Research & Development
Purpose.Description: Supports exploratory research and testing. Find out more [here] (https://www.boston.gov/departments/transportation/pick-and-drop-pilot-passenger-cars)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Safety & Security
Purpose.Description: Enables a safe and/or secure environment, for example for the purposes of [fire safety] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_safety), [home security] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_security) or ensuring safe passage in places such as [airports] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airport_security) or [roads] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Road_traffic_safety)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Switch
Purpose.Description: Supports a mechanical function - such as turning a device on or off, opening or closing, or adjusting brightness and intensity.
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Waste Management
Purpose.Description: Supports the handling and disposal of waste, including as [recyclables] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recycling), [compost] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compost) and [hazardous materials] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazardous_waste}. Find out more about [waste management] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waste_management)
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Purpose.Name: Water Efficiency
Purpose.Description: Reduces water use and/or helps conserve water. Find out more about water [efficiency] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_efficiency) and [conservation] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_conservation), and [green infrastructure] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_infrastructure).
Purpose.Headline: Purpose of this technology

Technology%20Type.Description: Measures various aspects of air quality, such as [pollen] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollen), [particulate matter] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particulate_pollution), [ozone] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozone#Ozone_in_Earth's_atmosphere), and [greenhouse gases] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_gas). Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Air Quality

Technology%20Type.Description: Provides access to assistive services. Examples include [assistive technologies] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assistive_technology) and [virtual assistants] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_assistant)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Assistance Station

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects [still images] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image#Characteristics) of a sufficient resolution where individuals can be identified, for example by capturing images of faces or unique numbers such as vehicle license plates. However, images are processed in a way that removes identifying characteristics before it is used or stored (known as *de-identified before first use* or *de-identified on device*), for example by blurring faces using [computer vision] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision). Find out more about [de-identification] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-identification)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: De-identified Image

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects [video footage] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video) of a sufficient resolution where individuals can be identified, for example by capturing images of faces or unique numbers such as vehicle license plates. However, the video is processed in a way that removes identifying characteristics before it is used or stored (known as *de-identified before first use* or *de-identified on device*), for example by blurring faces using [computer vision] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision). Find out more about [de-identification] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-identification)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: De-identified Video

Technology%20Type.Description: Audio data is collected that does or can identify individuals, either through manual review or technologies that can determine either what is being said, or who is saying it. Find out more about [speech recognition] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition) or [speaker recognition] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_recognition). Data is processed in a way that removes identifying characteristics before it is used or stored (known as *de-identified before first use* or *de-identified on device*). Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-identification)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: De-identified Voice

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects [still images] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image#Characteristics) of a sufficient resolution where individuals can be identified, for example by capturing images of faces or unique numbers such as vehicle license plates. Identifying information can be collected either through manual review of images by a person, or through [computer vision] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision) techniques that derives information in the form of data from images.
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Identifiable Image

Technology%20Type.Description: A wireless communication protocol for electronic devices that are within a short distance of each other, typically used in ticketing or payment systems. In this case, unique identification is possible, for example if a particular item is closely associated with an individual's [personal data] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_data). Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Near-field_communication)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Identifiable NFC

Technology%20Type.Description: Enables the identification of items using electromagnetic fields, commonly used to track inventory in stores. In this case, unique identification is possible, for example if a particular item is closely associated with an individual's [personal data] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_data). Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-frequency_identification)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Identifiable RFID

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects [video footage] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video) of a sufficient resolution where individuals can be identified, for example by capturing images of faces or unique numbers such as vehicle license plates. Identifying information can be collected either through manual review by a person, or through [computer vision] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision) techniques that derives information in the form of data from video or images.
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Identifiable Video

Technology%20Type.Description: Audio data is collected that does or can identify individuals, either through manual review or by technologies that can determine either what is being said, or who is saying it. Find out more about [speech recognition] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition) or [speaker recognition] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_recognition).
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Identifiable Voice

Technology%20Type.Description: Uses lasers to measure distances to objects, collecting data that can create a 3-D representation of the object. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lidar)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: LiDAR

Technology%20Type.Description: A device that collects audio. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microphone)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Microphone

Technology%20Type.Description: A wireless communication protocol for electronic devices that are within a short distance of each other, typically used in ticketing or payment systems. No identifying data is collected in this case. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Near-field_communication)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: NFC

Technology%20Type.Description: An electronic sensor that measures infrared (IR) light radiating from objects in its field of view. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passive_infrared_sensor)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Passive Infrared Sensor

Technology%20Type.Description: Uses radio waves to detect objects, or measure how they are moving through a space, such as vehicles. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Radar

Technology%20Type.Description: Enables the identification of items using electromagnetic fields, commonly used to track inventory in stores, but not for identifying individual items. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-frequency_identification)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: RFID

Technology%20Type.Description: Soil moisture sensors measures the water content in soil. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soil_moisture_sensor)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Soil Moisture Sensor

Technology%20Type.Description:
Takes acoustic measurements, most typically for measuring noise pollution. Find out more [here] 
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sound_level_meter)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Sound Level Meter

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects [still images] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image#Characteristics). Find out more about cameras [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camera)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Still camera

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects still images in the [infrared] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared_photography) portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Still camera - infrared

Technology%20Type.Description: Measures the temperature of or changes of temperature in the physical environment, and quantifies those attributes according to a standardized scale such as Celsius or Fahrenheit. Find more more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermometer)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Thermometer

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects video footage. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video).
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Video camera

Technology%20Type.Description: Collects video footage in the [infrared] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared_photography) portion of the electromagnetic spectrum.
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Video camera - infrared

Technology%20Type.Description: Measures various aspects of water quality, such as the amount of dissolved oxygen in water, pH, nitrates and dissolved oxygen. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_quality)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Water Quality

Technology%20Type.Description: A set of instruments for measuring atmospheric conditions such as temperature, precipitation, wind speed and direction, and barometric pressure. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_station)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Weather Station

Technology%20Type.Description: Allows two devices to establish a direct connection, without requiring a wireless router. When a device enters the range of the Wi-Fi Direct host, the device and host can communicate wirelessly, even if they are from different manufacturers. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi_Direct)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Wi-Fi Direct

Technology%20Type.Description: Provides wireless access to a wired computer network, or to the internet. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_access_point)
Technology%20Type.Headline: How this technology works
Technology%20Type.Name: Wireless Access Point

Data%20Type.Description: Measurements that are collected at regular intervals over a period of time. For example see [time series data] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_series).
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Values / Time

Data%20Type.Description: A digital image is composed of a grid of individual pixels. Find out more at [digital image] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_image)
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Pixel-based Image

Data%20Type.Description: Data that has one of two data values, for example true and false. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_data_type)
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Boolean

Data%20Type.Description: Data that is stored in a table, where values are stored in rows and columns. More [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_(information))
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Tabular

Data%20Type.Description: Data that represents a location, such as an address, a place name or geographic coordinates; or a structure, such as a floorplan. Find out more about [geospatial data] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_data_and_information) and [building information models] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Building_information_modeling)
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Spatial

Data%20Type.Description: Compressed data into a binary format. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_file)
Data%20Type.Headline: Type of data collected
Data%20Type.Name: Binary

Data%20Process.Name: RDUA Approved
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes a review process conducted before this technology was implemented
Data%20Process.Description: Data activity has undergone a Responsible Data Use Assessment and determined to provide a net benefit. The RDUA is a process that Sidewalk Labs conducts prior to the start of any data activity.

Data%20Process.Name: Reviewed Internally
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes a review process conducted before this technology was implemented
Data%20Process.Description: Many organizations have internal review processes that consider the potential benefits, risks and implications for privacy for new technologies or data collection activities. For example, in Canada, Privacy Impact Assessments are often conducted by organizations prior to the beginning for a project - find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privacy_Impact_Assessment). *This could be customized with the details of the accountable entity responsible for these instances of technology in the public realm*

Data%20Process.Name: Encrypted
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data has been encoded so that only authorized parties can access it, which can reduce risk related to handling private or sensitive information. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption)

Data%20Process.Name: Aggregated
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data that has been grouped or summarized from individual measurements, for example to count up totals or to calculate an average. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aggregate_data)

Data%20Process.Name: Raw data
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data that has not been processed or altered from the point of collection - the data is effectively identical to how it was gathered from the original data source. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raw_data)

Data%20Process.Name: Regulated
Data%20Process.Headline: A regulatory entity has oversight of this technology or data activity
Data%20Process.Description: Depending on the jurisdiction and type of data, data is regulated in various ways. For example, Personal Information in Canada is regulated by federal, provincial, and municipal laws. The collection, use and disclosure of Personal Information by private companies in Ontario is regulated by the [Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act] (https://www.priv.gc.ca/en/privacy-topics/privacy-laws-in-canada/the-personal-information-protection-and-electronic-documents-act-pipeda/) *This should be customized for the jurisdiction where this digital channel is being used*

Data%20Process.Name: AI System
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data that is processed by automated, algorithmic or artificial intelligence systems to derive a new result or data point. Find out more about [automated] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_decision_support), [algorithmic] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm) and [artificial intelligence] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) systems.

Data%20Process.Name: De-identified
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data that is processed to remove identifying values, usually to protect privacy. De-identification can happen at any point in a data collection process, for example before it is stored in a database, or before it is published. Here we define it to mean after the data has already left a hardware device, or after it has been stored in a database. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-identification)

Data%20Process.Name: In Device De-identified
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Data that is processed to remove identifying values, usually to protect privacy. De-identification can happen at any point in a data collection process, for example before it is stored in a database, or before it is published. Here we define it to mean before the data has already left a hardware device or been stored in a database. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-identification)

Data%20Process.Name: Not available to the accountable organization
Computer Vision
Data%20Process.Headline: Describes how data collected or handled by a technology is processed or manipulated
Data%20Process.Description: Computer vision refers to computer science methodologies that enable computers to derive data from digital images or video. Find out more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_vision)

Access.Name: Available to download
Access.Description: Data that can be accessed and downloaded online, either for free or for a fee
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Available to 3rd parties
Access.Description: Data is available to 3rd parties not involved in the data collection activity. This data is not being resold.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Available to me
Access.Description: Available to me but not to other individuals. For example, as an individual you have access to all your electronic toll records for your car, but other individuals do not have access to that.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Not available to me
Access.Description: Not available to me or other individuals. As an individual, there isn't a way for you to access this data.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Available for resale
Access.Description: The data collected may be resold to other 3rd parties
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Not available to the accountable organization
Access.Description: Data is not available to the accountable organization.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Not available to vendor
Access.Description: Data is not available to the data collection or technology provider *this can be customized*
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Available to the accountable organization
Access.Description: Data is available to the accountable organization.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Available to vendor
Access.Description: Data is available to the data collection or technology provider, who is responsible for delivering and maintaining hardware.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Owned by Accountable Party
Access.Description: The City of Boston will own and retain all ownership to the data collected within this pilot.
Access.Headline: Data Ownership

Access.Name: Temporarily Available to Vendor
Access.Description: The vendor will have unlimited access to the data for the purposes of providing calibration and analysis support during the four month duration of this project.
Access.Headline: Data Access

Access.Name: Retained for 6 months after publication of study results

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Stored on 3rd Party Cloud
Storage.Description: The aggregate data is stored on behalf of the accountable organization at an off-site data center.

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: No data retained
Storage.Description: No data is kept or stored

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained 24 hours
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 24 hours, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained 1 month
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 1 month, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained 3 months
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 3 months, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained for *time period*
Storage.Description: Data is stored for *a customized time period*, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained 1 year
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 1 year, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained 5 years
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 5 years, and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: How long is the data kept?
Storage.Name: Retained indefinitely

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Stored locally
Storage.Description: Data is stored in the jurisdiction where it was collected. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Stored primarily locally
Storage.Description: Data is stored mainly in the jurisdiction where it was collected. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Stored primarily internationally
Storage.Description: Data is stored outside the jurisdiction where it was collected. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Backed up locally
Storage.Description: Data is backed up with the jurisdiction where it was collected. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Backed up internationally
Storage.Description: Data is backed up outside the jurisdiction where it was collected. Find out more [here] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)

Storage.Name: Retained for 6 months after publication of study results
Storage.Description: Data is stored for 6 months after the publication of study results (estimated late 2020) and after this time period is deleted

Storage.Headline: Where is the data stored?
Storage.Name: Anonymized Aggregate Data Stored on 3rd Party Cloud
Storage.Description: The aggregate data is stored on behalf of the city of Boston in Amazon Web Services, an off-site data center.

Storage.Headline: How long is data kept?
Storage.Name: No Raw Data Retained
Storage.Description: Image data is retained for 30 seconds. A small fraction of images, approximately one every hour, are used for calibration and are retained for 30 days on a secure server.
